title: Pizza Express fears mount with debts estimated at £1.8m per restaurant
text:
Fears are rising for Pizza Express as investors raised doubts about whether it will fully pay off its massive debts – estimated at £1.8million per restaurant.

It is labouring under more than £1.1billion of borrowing, costing £93million a year to service.

That led to the chain, which has 620 restaurants and employs 14,000 people, posting a £55million loss last year.

Debt burden: Pizza Express is labouring under more than £1.1bn of borrowing, costing £93m a year to service. The chain, which employs 14,000 people, posting a £55m loss last year

Creditors, owed £650million, have reportedly brought in advisers for crisis talks as they fear they will not get their money back.

Pizza Express insiders claim it will not fold as it does not have to pay the debt back until 2021.

But Fiona Cincotta, an analyst at City Index, said: ‘The markets don’t believe the debt is going to be fully paid off.

Debt is a serial killer as far as restaurants are concerned.’

Luke Johnson, former chairman of the chain, said: ‘It will not disappear, but I suspect lenders may take a haircut.’

Many believe Pizza Express will require a financial restructuring, which could involve the lenders swapping their debt for a share of the company.

Chinese private equity owner Hony Capital bought the chain for £900million in 2014.
